isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - CHASSIS ACCESSORIES - OPERATION - Two Speed Axle Wiring With Manual or Non-Electronic Automatic Transmission

svcproc.title: Two Speed Axle Wiring With Manual or Non-Electronic Automatic Transmission
svcproc.para: When the key switch (24) is placed in the ignition or accessory position, power is applied to circuit 12, accessory feed block (J2), circuit 12A, fuse F14. From the fuse, power is applied to circuit 93, connector (14), and circuit M1BLUE to the two speed axle switch (55) for manual transmission or switch (75) with automatic transmissions.

When the switch is in the LOW position, power is applied to circuit M1BROWN, connector (59) and circuit M1BROWN with manual transmission, connector (14), and circuit 93A to the engine Electronic Control Module (ECM). This causes the ECM to adjust the signal being sent to the speedometer and odometer in order to show the correct speed and mileage for the gear ratio change.

With an electric shift motor, power at connector (14) and circuit 93B is applied to circuit 93B, dash/chassis connector (13), and a brown wire to the electric shift motor (703). This causes the axle to be in the LOW range.
When equipped with an air shift solenoid (263), power is not available at the solenoid and the two speed axle will be in LOW range.

When the switch is moved to the HIGH position, power is applied to circuit M1RED, connector (59) and circuit M1RED with manual transmissions, connector 14, circuit 93C, dash/chassis connector (13), and a red wire to the axle shift solenoid or the electric shift motor. This causes the axle to be shifted to the HIGH range.

With the selector switch in the HIGH position, power is removed on circuit 93A to the engine ECM. This causes the ECM to adjust the signal being sent to the speedometer and odometer in order to show the correct speed and mileage for the gear ratio change.
